thread.title: Crowds back Labour's plans to scrap tuition fees, nationalise water companies and invest in the NHS

author: Chris Knight
title: Crowds back Labour's plans to scrap tuition fees, nationalise water companies and invest in the NHS
text:
Crowds back Labour's plans to scrap tuition fees, nationalise water companies and invest in the NHS Organised by campaign group Momentum, dozens turned out following Jeremy Corbyn's earlier manifesto announcement Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Political activists and enthusiasts flooded the heart of Newcastle for a rally following the announcement of Labour’s manifesto. 
Scores of onlookers gathered at Grey’s Monument on Tuesday evening, the scene of a large anti-Donald Trump rally back in February. 
Unveiled by leader Jeremy Corbyn earlier in the day, Labour’s manifesto revealed pledges totalling £48.6 billion which they argue will be subsidised from extra tax revenue. Candidate Ian Mearns at a Labour Party rally in Newcastle City Centre (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
It included promises of billions in additional funding for the NHS and schools, as well as the nationalisation of water companies and the scrapping of university tuition fees. 
Chants of “Theresa May, hear us say, Jeremy Corbyn is on his way” rang out before speakers including Labour candidate for Gateshead Ian Mearns addressed the crowds. 
He said: “I think today’s publication of the manifesto by the Labour Party shows there is a distinct choice at this election . Supporters at a Labour Party rally in Newcastle City Centre (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
“If Theresa May and the Tories are elected, we know what’s coming. Their record over the last seven years shows that. 
“What we’ve given today is a real alternative. This isn’t just an election about Brexit, it’s an election about who governs the country for the next five years, who for and who by.” 
Organised by grassroots campaign group Momentum, the open rally was also attended by Kim McMurray - a key figure in the campaign of former US presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders. Supporters at a Labour Party rally in Newcastle City Centre (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Briefly addressing the crowds, she said: “This fight is now global. It’s about creating a world that works for working people, and a government that works for us. Read More 
“This is a manifesto we can get behind and get excited about.” 
Among those in attendance were Dunston mum Kerry Lister-Pattinson and her five-year-old daughter Lyla. 
Kerry, 31, said: “We’re big Jeremy Corbyn supporters, I was not a Labour voter until he became leader. Supporters at a Labour Party rally in Newcastle City Centre (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
“When Lyla turns 18, I want her to vote at the first opportunity, and I want her to understand what she’s voting for and what politics means to her.” Read More Bernie Sanders campaigner in Newcastle for Labour party manifesto launch 
Following speeches at Monument, Ms McMurray then led an activist training session at the nearby Tyneside Irish Centre. 
The sessions were aimed at guiding enthusiasts on how best to spread the word about Labour, whether it be on the doorstep, on social media, or on street stalls. Like us on Facebook
